list_page_teaser: I often get my friends to answer the questionnaire so I can learn more about them and draw their image.  View this gallery to see the resultant images, and learn about them as well.
description_html:
These are some images of my friends, from when I wrote the original version when I was in grad school.

These are images of real live normal people, whom I have known for many years!

image_list.title: Jim Armstrong
image_list.subtitle_html: A Best Friend Forever
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Jim was one of my best friends for many years when I was growing up in Richmond, Virginia.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in Jim's spiritual portrait represents his passion.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.  Jim was one of the warmest, friendliest people I have ever met!
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in Jim's spiritual portrait represents his realism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.  In those days I would frequently vote for third parties (that ended in 2000), but Jim was more realistic and, to my knowledge anyway, always voted Democratic.
image_list.story_html_intro: When I lived in Richmond, Jim was one of my best friends. He was the center of a group of us and the only one ....
When I lived in Richmond, Jim was one of my best friends. He was the center of ....
image_list.story_html:
When I lived in Richmond, Jim was one of my best friends. He was the center of a group of us and the only one I have seen to score 100% Extraverted on the Keirsey Temperament Sorter.

Working my way through school, spare time was rare, and if some free time opened up, I of course wanted to make the best of it. Whenever this happened, Jim was at the top of my list to find out what was going on with everyone in our gang.

If there was something happening with one of our friends, Jim always knew about it. Not only that, he would always invite people to join in — if he could, of course. This is what it means to be Extraverted!

The Red and Yellow in his portrait shows that Jim was a very outgoing, warm, and friendly person. And I regret I must say was, because Jim passed away April 5th, 2002.

Many years later, a lot of us from the old group continue stay in touch on Facebook. Jim helped us form relationships that have lasted longer than he did!

I know for a fact I am not alone in missing him very much, even after all these years!

image_list.title: Eric Erickson
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Eric was a good friend of mine in Richmond.  He passed away recently.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Eric's dominant trait, his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Eric's auxiliary trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.
image_list.story_html_intro: Eric was an out-going, open, cheerful friend. He loved music and we had many good times, going to concerts, hanging out down by the river, always ....
image_list.story_html:
Eric was an out-going, open, cheerful friend. He loved music and we had many good times, going to concerts, hanging out down by the river, always drinking and smoking.

When punk rock came along he was — unlike some of my friends — open to the newer sounds. Ultimately, though, Cat Stevens was his favorite artist.

He had a great laugh and was hard-working and smart, but after completing high school, had no interest in furthering his education. As we grew older and less resilient to the after effects of partying, most of us learned how to abstain or at least moderate. Eric was one exception to this general trend among my friends, as we grew into our thirties and beyond.

At one point he read some Nietzsche. This seemed to fuel his drinking and make him more apathetic about life in general and the future in particular. Ultimately he became a very tragic figure.

Eric passed away on November 26, 2016. His spirit was as unique as this portrait of it, and I am glad to have this image of his personality to remember him by.

image_list.title: Bill E
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: I have known Bill since the fifth grade.  We used to play trucks together!  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Bill's dominant trait, his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Bill's auxiliary trait, his passion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.

image_list.title: Bob N
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Bob and I have been to see many concerts together.  We have even seen the Rolling Stones a few times!  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Bob's dominant trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Bob's auxiliary trait, his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.

image_list.title: Buddy H
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Buddy and I have been friends since High School.  We were roommates for awhile in a four-bedroom flat that cost $160 per month!  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Buddy's dominant trait, his idealism.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Buddy's auxiliary trait, his passion.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.

image_list.title: Dave G
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Dave and I went to Graduate School together (but in different programs).  He helped me get my start in Colorado, but now lives in Hawaii.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Dave's dominant trait, his idealism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Dave's auxiliary trait, his passion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.

image_list.title: Greg L
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Greg and I have been friends for many years.  He used to be 'famous' for having annual Snakebite Parties!  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Greg's dominant trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Greg's auxiliary trait, his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.

image_list.title: Tom P
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Tom and I have been friends since Elementary School.  In junior high and high school we were both in band, and at one time we both played in a classic rock band named Snowball!  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Tom's dominant trait, his idealism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Tom's auxiliary trait, his rationality.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.

image_list.title: Roy B. Scherer
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Roy Scherer is a friend I met through some of my Libertarian friends when I lived in Richmond, Virginia.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in Roy's spiritual portrait represents his pragmatism.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in Roy's spiritual portrait represents his preference for making logical decisions.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.
image_list.story_html_intro: When I wrote the original version of the Groja © Program in college in Richmond, Virginia, I was very interested in Libertarianism. During that time ....
image_list.story_html:
When I wrote the original version of the Groja © Program in college in Richmond, Virginia, I was very interested in Libertarianism. During that time I was able to get Roy B. Scherer to answer the questions in the Keirsey Temperament Sorter. Roy is still a Libertarian who continues to lobby in Richmond Virginia for gun rights and the legalization of marijuana.

Here is an image of his personality. One might think that marijuana legalization would be a passionate issue, but his portrait shows that, for him at least, it was largely a matter of logic.
